docs.abstract: Gadgetwise blog highlights new Mythos XTR-50 speakers from Definitive Technology; speakers are $699 each; photos (S)

headline.main: Mythos Speakers Are Made to Match a Superthin TV

docs.lead_paragraph: So you just plunked down a bundle for that new superthin LED-backlit LCD or plasma TV, and you have even mounted it on the wall. What do you do to keep that slim look when it comes to audio equipment? If you are an audiophile with money, you might want to take a look at the new Mythos XTR-50 speakers from Definitive Technology. At $699 each, Definitive is positioning them as ''the world's thinnest high-performance on-wall home theater loudspeaker.''

docs.abstract: Apple announces that it plans to begin selling its iPad tablet computer in United States on April 3; will initially sell $499 models that connect to Internet via Wi-Fi networks, with versions that can tap into mobile phone networks to follow at end of April (S)

headline.main: Apple Plans To Begin Selling Its iPad On April 3

docs.lead_paragraph: Apple said on Friday that it would start selling its iPad multimedia tablet in the United States on April 3, a few days later than originally planned. The company will initially sell models that connect to the Internet using Wi-Fi networks, starting at $499. Versions that can also tap mobile phone networks will be available in late April, Apple said. When Apple introduced the iPad in January, the company said it would be available in March. Apple said that all iPad models would be available in Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Spain, Switzerland and Britain in late April. Stock in Apple, which is based in Cupertino, Calif., rose $8.24, or 3.9 percent, to $218.95.

docs.abstract: Lawson Software forecasts third-quarter profit below analysts estimates of 7 cents to 9 cents a share on revenue of $174 million to $178 million; says it has agreed to buy health care software provider Healthvision Solutions for $160 million (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Lawson Software forecast third-quarter profit below analysts' estimates and said it would buy a health care software provider, Healthvision Solutions, in an all-cash deal valued at $160 million. Shares of Lawson, which makes software for businesses, fell as much as 8 percent in aftermarket trade. The purchase of Healthvision, which is privately held, will help Lawson Software expand its footprint in the health care software market, its chief executive, Harry Debes, said in a call with analysts. Lawson Software forecast third-quarter earnings of 7 cents to 9 cents a share, excluding special items, on revenue of $174 million to $178 million. Analysts had expected earnings of 10 cents a share, excluding one-time items, on revenue of $174.9 million.
